channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Cuban Blogger Who Reveres Castro Pushes for Reform
item.description: Elaine Díaz may be the most important Cuban dissident you’ve never heard of. But that is perhaps because she doesn’t even call herself a dissident.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF

item.title: Mandela Remains in Intensive Care
item.description: Well-wishers gathered to pray for the former South African president as he spent a fourth day in intensive care for a lung infection.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: A mural of Nelson Mandela, the former South African president in downtown Johannesburg.

item.title: Turkish Police Push Into Square Near Park Protest
item.description: Efforts to disperse demonstrators from Taksim Square began a day after the prime minister agreed to meet with representatives of the protesters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Riot police tried to clear Taksim Square, where relatively few protesters appeared to be gathered.

item.title: Greece Shutting Down State Broadcaster Net
item.description: In a surprise move that angered labor unions and its junior partners, the conservative-led coalition government said the station, Net, would stop broadcasting at midnight Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Employees of the state broadcaster Net protest at the company's headquarters north of Athens.

item.title: The Female Factor: Drawing on the Suffragettes' Legacy
item.description: There's a rush of British interest in the suffrage movement of the early 20th century, as seen in a BBC comedy series. Some are also using the moment to reflect on what still has not been achieved.
item.dc:creator: By AMELIA GENTLEMAN

item.title: Teenager’s Death Reveals Growing Anger in Syria
item.description: Witnesses said radical Islamists in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo pulled 14-year-old Muhammad al-Qatta from his coffee kiosk on Sunday and later executed him.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: In Bond Case, German Court Debates Fate of Euro
item.description: At a hearing considering whether measures to contain the European crisis are legal, a debate on the euro project itself has erupted.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: The Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, Germany, heard arguments on Tuesday about whether E.C.B. measures to contain the euro crisis infringed on German law.

item.title: French Prosecutors Seek to Drop Charges Against Strauss-Kahn
item.description: The prosecutors cited insufficient evidence to keep Dominique Strauss-Kahn, charged with involvement in a prostitution ring, under formal investigation.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Becoming ‘Asia Literate’: Learn Chinese, but Don’t Stop There
item.description: As initiatives are under way around the world for non-Chinese to learn the language, some say there’s more to Asia than China; and more to becoming “China Literate” than learning the language.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By SUE-LIN WONG
item.media:credit: Theodore Kaye for The New York Times
item.media:description: College and high school students in Kazakhstan learning Chinese.

item.title: Taliban Bomb Kills Court Workers in Kabul
item.description: The attack killed at least 17 people and came just hours after the top United Nations envoy in Afghanistan said militants were willing to talk about lowering civilian deaths.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: A victim of a bomb attack outside Kabul's Supreme Court complex on Tuesday.

item.title: Taliban Bomb Kills Court Workers in Kabul
item.description: The attack killed at least 17 people and came just hours after the top United Nations envoy in Afghanistan said militants were willing to talk about lowering civilian deaths.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: A victim of a bomb attack outside Kabul's Supreme Court complex on Tuesday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 11
item.description: A girl playing at a park in New Delhi
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A girl playing on a makeshift swing at a park in New Delhi.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: French Foodies Fight Boil-in-a-Bag Trend
item.description: To the alarm of France’s gastronomes, a growing number of restaurants now offer pre-prepared meals. Now some want to change the law to limit the word “restaurant” to those that serve the real thing.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Eric Briffard, a top French chef, selecting ingredients at a Paris market.

item.title: Dialogue Between North and South Korea Collapses
item.description: Talks planned for this week between the neighbors have been called off after a dispute over which delegates the countries would send.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Suicide Bombers Attack in Central Damascus
item.description: At least 14 people were killed on Tuesday after two bombs were detonated in a square in the Syrian capital, according to the state news agency.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: South Korea’s Ex-Intelligence Chief Accused of Meddling in Presidential Race
item.description: Won Sei-hoon was accused of being involved in a secretive campaign in which his agency hired bloggers to post negative commentaries about rivals of President Park Geun-hye.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Air Controller Strike in France Causes Cancellations
item.description: Air traffic controllers in France on Tuesday began a three-day strike to protest European Union plans to accelerate the integration of the region’s fragmented air space.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: India Ink: Tourists Still Coming to India but at Slower Pace
item.description: According to a recent survey the number of foreign tourists visiting India had fallen 25 percent since December 2012, with a 35 percent drop among female travelers.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Tourists walking past Indian policemen near the Jama Masjid mosque in New Delhi on Sept. 19, 2010.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 11
item.description: The United States reconsiders military options in Syria; Ghana cracks down on Chinese migrants; high-profile rape cases discourage female tourists from going to India; the troika returns to Athens; and a brilliant showcase for the British sculptor William Turnbull.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Tourists in New Delhi. Visits to India by foreign women have fallen sharply this year, after several rape cases were reported.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara
item.description: Mr. Bharara on his profession, personal life and Indian roots.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVANI VORA

item.title: Shootings by Agents Increase Border Tensions
item.description: The deaths of at least 15 people by United States Border Patrol agents have spurred criticism of the agency, which some say has a lack of oversight and accountability.
item.dc:creator: By FERNANDA SANTOS
item.media:credit: Samantha Sais for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taide Elena’s grandson, José Antonio Elena Rodriguez, 16, was killed by Border Patrol agents.

item.title: Snowden, Facing Charges, Leaves Hong Kong Hotel
item.description: As the Justice Department moved to charge Edward J. Snowden with disclosing classified information, American officials said that he left a hotel in Hong Kong where he had been holed up for weeks.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, ERIC SCHMITT and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Enniskillen Journal: Northern Ireland Town Freshens Up Before Group of 8 Meeting
item.description: The town of Enniskillen, whose association with the country’s sectarian conflict still deters tourists, has undergone a makeover ahead of a summit meeting of world leaders.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers in Enniskillen, Northern Ireland, have been repainting buildings ahead of the Group of 8 meeting next week.

item.title: South Sudan Says Oil Will Flow Despite Sudan’s Threats
item.description: South Sudan said it would continue to pump oil for export through Sudan despite a threat by Sudan’s president to shut down the pipeline.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Readers Capture Istanbul’s Shifting Identity
item.description: Readers of The New York Times responded to a request to send in photographs that spoke to the kinds of change that sparked protests around Turkey.
